CatDescriptText: Samuel E. Coston, mail clerk, Oakland and Curtis Newring, railroad car inspector, Schenley Heights, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in the Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, September 17, 1960, pg. 11A with question: "Do you think Negroes choose their own leaders or are they chosen for them by someone else?" Mr. Coston's answer reads: "I think there is some pressure, but in most cases they choose their own leaders."  Mr. Newring's answer reads: "I think they are chosen by someone else in the majority, usually politicians, both Negro and white.  I don't know whether this is good or bad.  The Negro is vote-wise, but he is not politically wise.  he votes, yes, but for candidates chosen for him."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Samuel E. Coston wearing patterned necktie with clip and eyeglasses, standing in front of row of stores, Wood Street, Downtown; Portrait of Curtis Newring wearing paisley shirt, standing in front of stores and signs including RAAB Clothes and Dimlings Candy, Wood Street, Downtown
